title.narrative: Conservation of biodiversity in cultural parks

description.narrative: Conservation of globally significant biodiversity and sustainable use of ecosystem services in Algeria’s cultural parks.

title.narrative: photo 1 atelier de présentation des rapports
Photo réunion comité de pilotage 29 janv 2015
Conservation of biodiversity in cultural parks
Conservation of biodiversity in cultural parks

description.narrative: Conservation de la biodiversité dans les parcs culturels en Algérie.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
The national system of cultural parks in Algeria is managed to secure the conservation of globally significant biodiversity and sustainable use of ecosystem services.

1. Ecological sustainability. Elaboration, ratification and implementation of the general management plan for cultural parks, based on the principle of "inseparability of bio-cultural heritage" [including globally important biodiversity and ecosystem services].

comment.narrative: (i) Biodiversity action plan developed for the Tassili n'Ajjer and Ahaggar CPs. (ii) Principle of "inseparability" ratified under law 98-04 on the protection of cultural heritage.

(i) The application decrees of law 98-04 formally define the procedures for the development of the general management plan for cultural parks. (ii) The first General Management Plans are developed for the Tassili n'Ajjer and Ahaggar CPs.

Technical and legal expertise ongoing to develop GMP methodology and related application decree. Multi-sector collaborative platform established to optimise the mutual alignment of the Algerian CP system with the national biodiversity strategy under formulation.

description.narrative: 2. Institutional sustainability. A permanent body is established to supervise the management of the national system of cultural parks in Algeria.

comment.narrative: Algerian cultural parks are currently individually managed through dedicated institutions for each CP.
A permanent body for the management of Algerian CPs established with permanent staff and adequate technical and financial resources to carry out its missions.

Official posts and job descriptions for PC staff being redefined (preliminary report available as attachment N.1). Procedures involving competent authorities ongoing for the integration or staff recruited by the project as permanent government personnel.

description.narrative: 3. Sociocultural sustainability. Capitalisation of traditional knowledge cycles, particularly ecological know how within the PCs.

comment.narrative: Traditional ecological knowledge in Algerian CPs is poorly codified and capitalized.
Educational tools adopted for extracurricular school activities in the concerned wilayas, incorporate traditional ecological knowledge.
Initial assessment of cultural services in the Tassili Ahaggar region conducted (report available as attachment N.2).

description.narrative: The expanding national system of cultural parks manages ecosystems and biodiversity assets in a systematized, inclusive and efficient way over 850.670 km2.
4. Changes in capacity assessment scorecard for the national system of cultural parks.

Key planning, monitoring and reporting functions of the central CP management entity being actively developed, as detailed in report for first semester of 2015 (see attachment N.3).

description.narrative: 5. Financial Sustainability Scorecard

comment.narrative:
Component 1. Legal, regulatory & institutional frameworks: 51,2%
Component 2. Business planning and tools for cost-effective management: 49,2%
Component 3. Tools for revenue generation: 8,8%
Total score: 40,6%

Component 1. Legal, regulatory & institutional frameworks: 67%
Component 2. Business planning and tools for cost-effective management: 77,6%
Component 3. Tools for revenue generation:40,3%
Total score: 65,9%

Budgetary requirements and actual financial flows towards the CP system being re-assessed by the central PMU in collaboration with responsible parties within the Ministry of Culture and the management units of individuals CPs.

description.narrative: Public support for cultural parks expands the stakeholder base contributing to their conservation and management.
6. Dissemination of the CP concept among the target audience, measured through a system of periodic polling surveys.

comment.narrative:
To be defined through initial surveys / polls in terms of items dealing with the theme of CPs in Algeria:
- N. of articles in the national press (public and private).
- N. of online social networks.
- N. of visitors to the PPCA website.
- N. of cultural and scientific events.
- N. of programs on local radio stations.

- N. of articles in the national press (public and private).
- N. of online social networks.
- N. of visitors to the PPCA website.
- N. of cultural and scientific events.
- N. of programs on local radio stations.

IEC strategy and action plan for 5 years developed and under implementation (see attachment N.4). Baselines for indicator established as follows: (No.)
Press articles: 6 (Y1); 8 (Y2).
Radio programs :51 (Y1); 99 (Y2).
TV programs: 0 (Y1);13 (Y2).
Cultural/ scientific events : 1(Y1); 6 (Y2).
Social networks: 1(Y1); 2 (Y2).
Visitors PPCA website NA NA

description.narrative: Management effectiveness at the Tassili Nâ€™Ajjer and Ahaggar Cultural Parks is enhanced.
7. The overall score of the Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT).

comment.narrative:
METT scores
Tassili Nâ€™Ajjer : 65
Ahaggar CPs: 62

METT scores
Tassili Nâ€™Ajjer : 77
Ahaggar CPs: 78

Improvement of management effectiveness has been initiated on the ground in 3 of the 6 priority sites - Taessa, Tefedest and Tihodaine - by strengthening surveillance, biodiversity monitoring, infrastructure development, collaborative management and eco-development. Activities and results are detailed in combined project and CP staff mission reports and summarised in the project’s M&E report N.2 (see attachment N.3).

description.narrative: Threats and degradation of priority biodiversity conservation and Ramsar sites of the Tassili Nâ€™Ajjer and Ahaggar Cultural Parks are reduced.
8. Distribution of the cheetah population and density of key prey species.

comment.narrative: First phase estimates on the presence and density of prey species (to be verified).
Cheetah distribution and the density of key prey species is maintained or improves.

Due to difficulties in mobilising external TA, initial assessments of were conducted internally as part of the CP ecological monitoring program supported by the project, targeting the distribution and density of key species, including cheetah (latest monitoring reports available as file attachments N.5). Available baseline data: (i) cheetah presence confirmed in 5 of 6 priority sites during period 2005-2007); (ii) for the main prey species Dorcas gazelle (n. of individuals observed /km ) :
2005 : 0,23
2006 : 0,17
2007 : 0,47
2015 : 0,28 (based on limited sample)

description.narrative: Conservation of flagship species in the Tassili - Ahaggar region is enhanced.
9. The level of poaching recorded in priority sites.

comment.narrative: Baseline values obtained during phase 1 of Tassili-Ahaggar project to be verified.
The number of recorded poaching incidents decreases by 50%.

Poaching incidents are being monitored through the CP ecological monitoring program supported by the project. Baseline data available (n. of incidents observed per day of monitoring): 0,35/day (2005-2007); 0,5/day (first semester 2015/ (based on limited sample).

description.narrative: 10. Rate of loss of tree cover in priority biodiversity sites (N. of trees / ha).

comment.narrative: Average annual rate of loss of tree cover for 2000-2014 period to be determined at project start-up.
Tree cover is maintained or increases in biodiversity priority sites.

Field work conducted to relocate permanent sample plots established during the first phase and standardise methodologies to compare data sets across years. Terms of reference being developed and specialist team being identified for remote sensing assessment aiming to detect and measure changes in woody cover in the Tassili Ahaggar region over the last 3 decades.

description.narrative: 11. Water quality on Rasmsar sites.

comment.narrative: Baseline values for pollutants to be obtained from initial lab analyses.
To be quantified for key parameters, following initial lab analyses.

A methodology has been outlined to measure water quality in Ramsar sites, according to official Algerian protocols for water quality assessments. The initial collection and analysis of water samples will be conducted as part of the ongoing CP ecological monitoring program.

description.narrative: Strengthened sense of ownership by resource users and other stakeholders through the implementation of collaborative management agreements reduces pressure on ecosystem functions in the Tassili Nâ€™Ajjer and Ahaggar Cultural Parks.

12. Number of collaborative management (CM) agreements covering priority biodiversity sites in the CPs [Taessa 494 km2, Tefedest 6.085 km2, Imidir 11.160 km2, Serkout Anhef, 19,600 km2, TihodaÃ¯ne 1.404 km2, Meddak 2.445 km2].

comment.narrative: The preparation of CM agreements has been initiated for 5 priority sites during the first phase of the project.
CM agreements covering at least 6 priority sites are formalised and implemented.

Collaborative platforms involving all key stakeholders have been successfully established in 3 of the 6 priority sites. The negotiation of CM agreements is ongoing in each of the priority sites and should be finalised and formalised by the end of the year.

description.narrative: 13. Number of proposals originating from women that are integrated in the CM agreements.

comment.narrative: Baseline values obtained during phase 1 of Tassili -Ahaggar project to be verified.
Doubling of the number of proposals originating from women integrated in CM agreements.

Preliminary baselines established, based on gender disaggregated data originating from proposed CM agreements, still to be formalised (see indicator N.12) :
N. of proposals from women in CM agreements:.
Taessa: 4 (Phase 1); 4 (2015).
Tefedest :4 (Phase 1); 4 (2015).
Tihodaine: 1 (Phase 1); 5 (2015).

description.narrative: 14. Codification and capitalization of traditional ecological knowledge associated with adaptation to climate change.

comment.narrative: Traditional ecological knowledge on adaptation to climate change are not codified [e.g. mobility of herds, pasture management. water management, medicinal plants].
Traditional ecological knowledge on adaptation to climate change is codified and capitalized as part of CM agreements concluded.
Initial assessment of cultural services, conducted in the Tassili Ahaggar region, including those covering CC related adaptation (see indicator N.3 and attached report N.2).

description.narrative: Alternative livelihood approaches contribute to reducing pressures on productive ecosystem services and improving socio-economic status at priority sites in the two parks.
15. Co-financing mobilized for the implementation of eco-development actions and the fight against land degradation.

comment.narrative:
Allocated funds (to be updated):
TYPE OF ACTION | Budget
Pastoral water management | 2,918,611
Animal husbandry schemes | 900,000
Medicinal and forage plants | 1,111,111
Solar energy and alternative energy | 2,605,000
Reforestation | 883,333
Plant nurseries and seed banks | 458,333
Womenâ€™s traditional handicrafts | 800,903
Sustainable tourism | 1,914,236
Environmental Education | 770,819
Other eligible actions | 1,506,944
TOTAL | 13,869,292
Allocated funds are effectively mobilized for the implementation of eligible actions.

The proactive involvement of key government sectors has been catalysed and the procedures to secure the effective mobilisation of technical and financial resources discussed and adopted at two important workshops held in in the wilayas of Illizi and Tamanrasset during December 2014. The operational details for key sectoral interventions are being elaborated for the 3 priority sites presently targeted (see indicators N.12 -13). It is anticipated that the engagement of the various sectors and their respective budgetary inputs will be formalised by the end of this year.

description.narrative: 16. % of tour operators adopting the sustainable tourism charter developed for the Tassili-Ahaggar region.

comment.narrative: Sustainable tourism charter developed during first phase of Tassili-Ahaggar project.
At least 50% of certified tour operators adopt and implement sustainable tourism charter.

As a response to the ongoing security related limits on international tourism in the Tassili Ahaggar region, the project is refocussing towards the promotion of domestic tourism. Terms of reference have been developed and an expertise is being contracted to assist in elaborating a strategic action plan for the domestic tourism sector in the region.
